title-group.article-title: Three New Carnivorous sponge species (Demospongiae: Cladorhizidae) from the Seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge

sec.p: Three New Carnivorous sponge species ( Demospongiae : Cladorhizidae ) from the Seamounts of the Central Indian Ridge
PERIASAMY RENGAIYAN1 & BABAN INGOLE1*
1 National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research ( NCPOR ), Ministry of Earth Sciences (MoES), Headland Sada, Vasco-da-Gama, Goa, India —403804

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Deep-sea sponges are an imperative component of benthos. They accumulate the suspended organic matter by filtering large quantities of water and, with their intricate structures, provide the most suitable habitats for various associated organisms. We describe three new cadorhizid sponges from the Central Indian Ridge (CIR), Indian Ocean. The sponges are part of the benthic sledge collection conducted onboard the MGS Sagar in the CIR region. A detailed taxonomic description of two novel species, Asbestopluma ( Asbestopluma ) indiyansis sp. nov .
, and Asbestopluma ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
are provided based on the morphological and molecular (mtCOI and 28S) markers. In addition, another new carnivorous species Chondrocladia sagari sp. nov .
is described based on the morphological and mtCOI marker. The systematic and descriptions of new species are discussed based on the structural and phylogenetic analysis. Our study shows that the cladorhizid fauna of the seamounts from the CIR are unique and represent regionally endemic benthic habitats.

Key words: Porifera, deep-sea, Carnivorous sponge, Cladorhizidae , new species , Asbestopluma , Chondrocladia , DNA
barcodes, Central Indian Ridge, Indian Ocean

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The family Cladorhizidae is exceptional within the phylum Porifera. The family comprises an exciting group of deep-sea sponges with well-developed carnivory and (their) ability to entangle, capture passively, and envelop small groups of crustaceans. They are known for their unique carnivorous feeding strategy, an evolutionary adaptation to oligotrophic conditions in deep-sea water ( Vacelet & Boury-Esnault 1995 ), their diversity, and evolution ( Vacelet & Custódio 2007 ,
Hestetun et al . 2015
, 2016). Previously described cladorhizid species from the southwest Indian Ocean were based on the “ Challenger ” and second “ Galathea ” expeditions ( Ridley & Dendy 1886 , 1887 , Lévi 1964 ; Topsent (1909) and Koltun (1964) . The lack of systematic deep-sea biological surveys in the Central Indian Ridge (CIR) prompted detailed exploration in the seamount areas (
Rogers et al . 2010
, Rogers & Taylor 2012 ). The detailed studies of biodiversity, ecological role, and various functions of carnivorous species, from seamounts of the South West Indian Ridge (SWIR), were carried out by Rogers & Taylor (2012) ,
O’Loughlin et al . (2013)
,
Laptikhovsky et al . (2017)
, and
Djurhuus et al . (2017)
. A recent study by
Hestetun et al . (2017a)
suggested that benthic species in the upper bathyal of the southwest Indian Ocean Ridge ( SWIOR ) were unique and characterized by regionally endemic cladorhizid species.
Hestetun et al . (2017a)
described nine new cladorhizid species in the SWIOR seamounts based on RRS James Cook cruise JC066. Similarly, seventeen new species of carnivorous sponges were described from bathyal to abyssal depths off Eastern Australia during the RVInvestigator 2017 Abyss Expedition ( Ekins, Erpenbeck & Hooper 2020 ) from an expedition extending from the Coral Sea to the seamounts south of Tasmania (
O’Hara et al . 2020
).

An excellent systematic review of the family Cladorhizidae and closely related genera and their associated microscleres has been produced by
Hestetun et al . (2016)
. The species of the family Cladorhizidae are similar in morphological characters with biogeographical affinities and molecular studies support their biogeographical distribution along the SWIOR , southwest Pacific Ocean, and the southwest Atlantic Ocean. The CIR’s active hydrothermal vent fauna composition had links to both Atlantic Ocean and Pacific Ocean vent assemblage (
Van Dover et al . 2001
,
Hashimoto et al . 2001
,
Bachraty et al . 2009
,
Zhou et al . 2018
,
Surya Prakash et al . 2022
). The detailed benthic study of the active Edmond field showed the communities’ existence of an inactive megabenthic assemblage at the southern CIR (
Gerdes et al . 2019
), supporting higher habitat heterogeneity and rich diversity (
Cuvelier et al . 2014
).
Desbruyeres et al . (2006)
and
Bachraty et al . (2009)
reported the dependency of endemic species on the chemoautotrophic bacteria groups for food availability in the deep-sea ecosystems. However, there is a lack of information on the species diversity and distribution of carnivorous sponges in the CIR region. The previous study in CIR did not report any cladorhizid sponges, mainly because of poor sampling, and most of the cladorhzids are very small in size. Cladorhizid sponges have been a focus of many recent studies, yet species in the Indian Ocean and the neighboring regions remain unexplored. Therefore, in the present study, we describe three new species of Cladorhizid sponges from the Central Indian Mid-Oceanic Ridge, sampled near the active Edmond vent region and about 1.8 km away from the sampling sites at the northern CIR.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
All the sponge specimens are part of the benthic sledge collection conducted onboard the MGS Sagar in the CIR (cruise no: MGS35/36, March-May 2020;
& Table 1 ). The ultra-slowly spreading CIR extends southwestwards, beginning from the Central Indian Ridge system linking to the Mid-Atlantic Ridge system. This divergent plate boundary demarcates the African plates and Antarctic plates. It is separated at its southwest end through the Bouvet Triple Junction and at its North East end through the Rodrigues Triple Junction. All the megafauna, including sponges, were sorted, photographed, and stored in 70% ethanol until further laboratory analysis. The spicule preparations were carried out following the method of Boury-Esnault & Rützler (1997) . Spicule dimensions were measured and represented as a minimum–(mean)–maximum of lengths x widths of each spicule category under the stereo zoom light microscope (Leica DMC6200). Spicule preparations were made by dissolving the tissue in 15% sodium hypochlorite to remove the soft tissue, rinsed twice with neutralized double-distilled water, followed by rinsing with ethanol (70%) and ethanol (99%) for removal of water, and then air-dried. Finally, the spicules were gold sputter-coated for a Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) to improve the resolution (model no: SEM—JEOL JSM, Country—6360LV between the voltage range of 15–20 kV). All types of material are deposited in the National Center for Polar and Ocean Research ( NCPOR ) collection, Goa, India .

sec.title: Molecular analysis
sec.p:
A small piece of the sponge tissue was used for DNA extraction by the CTAB (Cetyltrimethylammoniumbromide) method (
Sambrook et al . 1989
), which is suitable for complex material (
Erpenbeck et al . 2016
). The Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) amplification of the partial 28S rRNA gene using primers, 28S-C2-F, and 28S-D2- R , and partial mtCOI gene segment were performed (
Chombard et al . 1998
,
Folmer et al . 1994
,
Rot et al . 2006
). In brief, 25-μl reaction solution consisting of 2.5 µL of 10x PCR buffer, 2.5 µL of 25 mM MgCl2, 1 µL of 10 mM dNTPs, 1 µL of each primer (10 µM), 17.2 µL of water, 0.3 µL of DNA polymerase, and 1 µL DNA template were used. The initial denaturation temperature was 94° C for 5 minutes, followed by 34 cycles consisting of 40 seconds of denaturation (temperature 94° C), 40 seconds annealing (60°C for the 28S gene and 49°C for mtCOI), followed by 1 minute elongation at 72° C, and final elongation at 72° C for 5 minutes. Further, the PCR products were purified using ExoSap IT, and the purified PCR products were sequenced on an ABI 3500 automated sequencer (Thermofisher,) method using the BigDye-Terminator Mix v3.1. DNA sequences thus obtained were trimmed and assembled using CodonCode Aligner v 3.7.1 (www.codoncode.com). The sequence data obtained were further submitted in the NCBI GenBank database. The phylogenetic reconstructions were obtained for all Asbestopluma and Chondrocladia sequence data of the mtCOI and 28S genes. To confirm the taxonomic identity of the carnivorous sponges, aligned mtCOI and 28S genes datasets were closely compared to other carnivore sponge species retrieved from the NCBI GenBank database. MAFFT v7.313 was used for multiple sequence alignment ( Katoh & Standley 2013 ). Maximum likelihood (ML) reconstructions were performed using RAxML 8.0.26 ( Stamatakis 2014 ) under the GTRGAMMA model and 100 rapid bootstrap replicates. The reconstruction of phylogenetic trees was visualized in FigTree v1.4.4 ( Rambaut 2009 ).

Remarks. In terms of spicule measurements of A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
is closely related to A. ( A. ) jamescookiHestetun, Rapp & Xavier, 2017 , described earlier from seamounts in the Southwest Indian Ocean Ridge (
Hestetun et al . 2017a
), and A. ( A. ) desmophora Kelly & Vacelet, 2011
which was initially described from seamounts along the Macquarie Ridge in the vicinity of New Zealand , and subsequently recorded from seamounts in the eastern Solomon Islands ( Vacelet & Kelly 2014 ). Asbestopluma ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
differs from A. ( A. ) desmophora in lacking desmas, and acanthosubtylostrongyles (which appear to be unique in the latter species compared to other members of the genus), and in the shape of the two types of anisochelae. The larger anisochelae in A. ( A. ) desmophora and A. ( A. ) jamescooki are triangular and their upper ends are palmate, while in A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
upper end of the anisochelae is more rounded, with major notches between alae and the shaft of the anisochelae (
). The smaller palmate anisochelae are more rounded and with the alae covering the shaft in A. ( A. ) jamescooki than in A. ( A. ) desmophora . The same general spicule morphology in A. ( A. ) jamescooki from the SWIOR, from which A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
species from the CIR can be distinguished by geographical distance, general habitus, and other spicule measurements ( Table 2 ). A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
species has bifurcating habit similar to A. ( A. ) furcata Lundbeck, 1905
, A. ( A. ) jamescooki , and A. ( A. ) ruetzleriHestetun, Tompkins-Macdonald & Rapp, 2017 species, but these species differ from the others by the different shapes of anisochelae.

Molecular data based on mtCOI and 28S genes from this species has been included in a phylogenetic tree which shows a separate branch of A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .

sec.title: Phylogenetic results
sec.p:
In the present study, we described two new species under the subgenus Asbestopluma and one species under the genus Chondrocladia . All the specimens were successfully sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. The results obtained from the phylogenetic analysis are given in
(mtCOI) and
(28S). We used the DNA sequence of all recognized taxa providing a mtCOI and 28S dataset representing the complete set of known and unknown species of carnivorous (family Cladorhizidae ) sponges. The phylogenetic analysis shows the clear molecular separation, with new sequences clustering with closely related species Asbestopluma ( A. ) indiyansis sp. nov .
, A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov. ,
and Chondrocladia species
( Chondrocladia sagari sp. nov .
). Our results using the maximum likelihood method, support the new species position with a high bootstrap value of 98% and monophyly of species. Further, the phylogenetic analysis shows the evolutionary relationship of the genera Asbestopluma and Chondrocladia , which are comparable to those species described by
Hestetun et al . (2016
, 2017a , 2017b ),
Dressler-Allame et al . (2017)
,
Ekins et al . (2020)
. Of the three CIR new species: A. ( A. ) indiyansis sp. nov .
is a sister species to A. ( A. ) pseudoisochelaHestetun, Rapp & Xavier, 2017 from the SWIOR with high bootstrap support (100%), A. ( A. ) cf. belgicae ( Topsent, 1901 )
from the Southern Ocean and A. ( A. ) pennatula (Schmidt, 1875)
from the North-East Atlantic. Whereas, A. ( A. ) bharatiyae sp. nov .
is a sister species to A. ( A. ) jamescooki described by Hestetun et al . 2017 from the SWIOR and A. ( A. ) desmophora Kelly & Vaceleet, 2011
from the southwest Pacific with high support based on mtCOI and 28S genes sequence (
). Further, based on the present phylogenetic analysis, Chondrocladia sagari sp. nov .
is recovered as a sister species to C. vaceleti described by Christobo et al . (2005) from the Angola Basin.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The MGS Sagar cruise 35/36 trawls the seamounts in the CIR which resulted in the discovery of three new species of carnivorous sponges.
Hestetun et al . (2017a)
discovered nine new carnivorous sponge species based on the RRS James Cook expedition along the SWIOR and considered these sponges as seamount endemic species given the comparatively unexplored nature of the area. So far, a total of 18 species of cladorhizid sponge have been reported from the Southwest Indian Ocean Ridge (
Hestetun et al . 2017a
, Table 7). Interestingly, none of the recently described sponge species were from the CIR region. These species perhaps demonstrate regional endemicity to the SWIOR seamount system which needs to be further confirmed by a more meticulous sampling of this vast area. The three new species described in our work from the CIR seamounts could also be regionally endemic, but this hypothesis has to be confirmed with comprehensive sampling and further studies in the CIR seamounts. The new species have similar morphology and spicule characters to A. ( A. ) pseudoisochela and A. ( A. ) jamescooki from the SWIOR (
Hestetun et al . 2017a
) and C. clavata from the Southern Ocean (
Dressler-Allame et al . 2017
). The reconstruction of phylogenetic trees based on mtCOI and 28S genes shows the relative position of new species in the monophyletic group with closely related Cladorhizidae species.

There has been a phenomenal rise in the discovery of new sponge species, especially of the deep-sea carnivorous sponges, mainly due to an increase in sampling efforts, advancement in deep-sea technology, and use of underwater photography (
Hestetun et al . 2019
). Moreover, the use of molecular techniques and vigilant examination of the older collections by subject experts has further accelerated the rate of redescription of old specimens in different museums from their original description reports (e.g.
Hestetun et al . 2017a
,b,
Ekins et al . 2020
). Hestetun et al . (2017) has described nine new cladorhizid species from the seamount of the SWIOR .
Dressler-Allame et al . (2017)
has reported 29 Cladorhizidae species, including two new species, from the Weddell Sea, Antarctica .
Ekins et al . (2020)
has recently discovered 17 new carnivorous sponge species (family Cladorhizidae ) from the Pacific Ocean and also redescribed four species, which were earlier described by Ridley and Dendy (1886 , 1887 ). Thus, while demonstrating the comprehensiveness of early works, the present study also highlights the need for reaffirming the old collections.

The essential biological factors for larval dispersal of deep-sea benthic fauna are near-bottom deep-water currents such as the Antarctic bottom water current and North Atlantic deep water current through abyssal basins (Mc-Clintock et al . 2005, Downey & Janussen 2015 ). In addition, other environmental factors such as the coastal gyres, stable environmental conditions, lecithotrophic larvae can also control the circum-Antarctic species dispersal (Mc-Clintock et al . 2005, Janussen & Downey 2014 ). In particular,
Ekins et al . (2016)
found astonishing levels of genetic connectivity in deep-sea ‘lithistid’ sponges, with a recovery of the same species across the Pacific Ocean, further confirming the connectivity and distributional pattern of carnivorous sponges (
Hestetun et al . 2019
). Janussen & Downey (2014) and
Göcke et al . (2016)
presented different distributional patterns for many Antarctic sponge species. As the molecular database of these carnivorous species grows, the description of new genera representing these morphological groups will become clearer from their molecular systematics. Although a recent comprehensive molecular study of cladorhizids has been published by
Hestetun et al . (2016)
, no comparable large-scale study has yet been made for the CIR species as to the extent of their connectivity across the Indian Ocean. Although,
Ekins et al . (2016)
found that deep-sea ‘lithistid’ sponge species have unexpected levels of connectivity amongst seamounts south of New Caledonia , more extensive collections across wider areas of the Pacific is required (
Hestetun et al . 2019
). Consequently, the use of remotely operated vehicles in future explorations will decide if the distributions of the two new species in the present study are restricted to the seamounts of CIR, or if they have more widespread distribution across the Indian Ocean. The discovery of three new carnivorous sponge species further supports the earlier findings that the Indian Ocean Mid-oceanic Ridge (MoR) system (Carlsberg Ridge, CIR, and SWIOR ) is having a higher species diversity of cladorhizid sponges in this region.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present study has shown that there are large areas of the CIR where cladorhizid diversity is poorly known, and therefore, the discovery of three new sponge species is as anticipated. It highlights the uniqueness of the Indian Ocean MoR seamount fauna with a high potential for the discovery of new/unknown species. More specifically, the regional endemic cladorhizid species can be anticipated in the CIR region in previously poorly sampled areas. Moreover, the phylogenetic analysis also suggests the similarity of the CIR species to the SWIOR , Pacific, and Atlantic Oceans. However, there is the potential need for detailed studies to examine possible correlations between geographic separation and similarity between these areas. More exploratory and survey work is being undertaken within, or near this region of the Indian Ocean, primarily by the International Seabed Authority and its collaborators, with the need for rigorous taxonomic work. Further work by the NCPOR in the area would likely recover more undescribed cladorhizids and other benthic species. Through that work, the NCPOR museum (Government of India ) will be capable of increasing its specimen holdings to demonstrate the deep-sea taxonomic groups better as they relate to marine benthic biodiversity in the Indian Ridge systems.
